translated: Treatise on Contemplating the Mind

It is said that contemplating the mind can be called realization. Another question: It is said above that true suchness, buddha-nature, and all merits take enlightenment as the root. I have not yet inquired about the mind of ignorance and all evils,
what do they take as their root? The answer is:
Although the mind of ignorance has 84,000 afflictions, desires, and countless, boundless evil deeds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges,
to take the essentials,
they are all based on the three poisons as their root.
The three poisons are greed, anger, and delusion.
This mind of the three poisons itself can fully possess all evils,
just like a large tree, although its root is one, the branches and leaves it produces are countless.
In the root of the three poisons, various evil karmic activities are produced.
They are a hundred thousand, ten million, a billion times more than the previous, and cannot be compared.
In this way, the mind itself becomes the three poisons in the fundamental substance.
If it manifests in response to the six sense organs, it is also called the six thieves.
The six thieves are called the six consciousnesses.
Coming out of and entering the six sense faculties, they are attached to myriad realms.
They are able to create evil karma and harm the essence of true suchness.
Therefore, they are called the six thieves.
All sentient beings, due to these three poisons and six thieves,
Are confused in body and mind, sinking in birth and death.
Revolving through the six realms, they experience various sufferings.
There are also rivers that, due to a small spring, flow continuously.
They are then able to spread out with billowing waves for myriad miles.
If someone were to cut off its original source,
Then all the currents would cease.
Those who seek liberation, by removing the three poisons and six thieves,ğŸ”½Can themselves eliminate all suffering.
He also asked:
The three realms and six destinies are vast and boundless.ğŸ”½If one only observes the mind, how can one avoid their suffering?
He replied:
The karmic retribution of the three realms is only produced by the mind.
If the mind originally does not exist, then there are no three realms.
The three realms are precisely the three poisons.
Greed is the desire realm.
Anger is the form realm.
Ignorance is the formless realm.
Because of these three minds, the karmic retributions of all evil deeds are accumulated and perfected, and the cycle of rebirth is not complete.
Therefore, it is called the three realms.
Moreover, due to the creation of karma by the three poisons, the different destinies of heavy and light retributions are divided into six destinies.
Therefore, it is called the six destinies. Another question:
How are the heavy and light retributions divided into six? The answer:
If there are sentient beings who do not understand the correct cause and cultivate goodness in a deluded mind,
They will not escape the three realms and will be reborn in the three light destinies.
What are the three light destinies?
They all cultivate the ten wholesome deeds, vainly seeking happiness.
They will not escape the realm of greed
and will be reborn in the six destinies.
They all uphold the five precepts, vainly giving rise to love and hatred.
They will not escape the realm of anger
and will be reborn as humans.
Deludedly clinging to conditioned existence, they believe in wrong teachings and seek blessings.
They will not escape the realm of delusion
and will be reborn as asuras.
Seeing these three types is called the three layers.
What are the three layers?
They refer to those who indulge in the three poisons and only create evil karma.
They will fall into the three heavy destinies.
If the karma of greed is heavy, one falls into the realm of hungry ghosts.ğŸ”½If the karma of anger is heavy, one falls into the hells.
If the karma of delusion is heavy, one falls into the animal realm.
Thus, these three heavy [karmas] together with the previous three light ones make the six destinies.
Therefore, know that all wholesome karma arises from one's own mind.
One only needs to concentrate the mind and avoid all evil.
The karmic activities of the three realms and six destinies will naturally be extinguished.ğŸ”½Being able to extinguish all suffering is called liberation.

The answer was:

Now, being able to remove the three kinds of poisonous minds of greed, anger, and delusion,

The sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age are foolish and dull-witted.
They do not understand the TathÄgata's secret teachings of the three asamkhyeya kalpas.

Wouldn't this cause practitioners who do not regress from bodhi to doubt that they will attain Buddhahood?
Now, learners only need to contemplate the mind and not cultivate precepts and practices.
How does one accomplish the accumulation of wholesome dharmas?

being able to restrain the three poisons, thus gathering the three kinds of wholesome dharmas in the mind, which is called the three collections of precepts.ğŸ”½PÄramitÄ

Because if one can uphold the three precepts, then all wholesome qualities are complete.

Benefiting oneself and others, universally saving all beings.

Since one knows that the precepts and practices cultivated are not apart from the mind,
If one's own mind is pure, then all meritorious virtues are also pure. It is also said:
If one wishes to attain a pure Buddha, one should purify one's mind.
In accordance with the purity of the mind, the Buddha land is pure.
If one can control the three poisonous minds,
The three collections of pure precepts will naturally be accomplished. It is also said:
As it is said in the sutra,
The six pÄramitÄs are also called the six perfections.

What is the meaning of the six pÄramitÄs? The answer is:
If one wishes to cultivate the six pÄramitÄs, one should purify the six sense faculties. If one wishes to purify the six sense faculties, one should first subdue the six thieves.
One is able to abandon the thief of the eyes.
Free from various forms and appearances, the mind is without concern or stinginess.
This is called giving. One is able to restrain the thief of the ears.

Not being in the lowlands,
Not eating grain, chaff, bran, or beans,
Not being in the same herd as a bull,
Having a body the color of purple gold,
This cow is none other than Vairocana Buddha.
Out of great compassion and pity,
In the pure essence, he nurtures all beings seeking liberation with the subtle Dharma milk of the three collections of pure precepts and the six pÄramitÄs.

The Buddha said:

Circumambulate stÅ«pas day and night, practice the Way, observe the precepts, and pay homage,
various merits all lead to the attainment of Buddhahood.
If one only contemplates the mind and comprehensively includes all practices,
such a matter should be false.
The Buddha's teachings are immeasurable and skillful.
All sentient beings have dull faculties and are narrow-minded and inferior.
The profound Dharma is likened to the conditioned and unconditioned.
If one does not practice internally but only seeks externally,
hoping to obtain blessings,
there is no such possibility.
As for the term monastery,
it is a Sanskrit word from the Western Regions.
In this land, it is translated as the ground of the pure abode.
If one permanently eliminates the three poisons and always purifies the six sense faculties,
with body and mind tranquil, the inside and outside are pure.
This is called cultivating the monastery.
Moreover, casting Buddha images
is what all sentient beings seeking Buddhahood do to cultivate the practices of enlightenment. How could it be dismissed as merely casting and writing in gold and bronze?

Therefore, those who seek liberation use the body as the furnace, the Dharma as the fire, and wisdom as the craftsman, with the three collections of pure precepts and the six perfections as the design.
They refine the true suchness of body and mind, the Buddha-nature.
They thoroughly enter all the molds of precepts.
They respectfully practice without deficiency or leakage.
They naturally accomplish the image of true appearance.
What they accomplish is the ultimate, eternally abiding, subtle, and wonderful form body, not the Dharma of conditioned arising and decay.
If a person seeks the Way but does not understand this,
how can they rashly say they have accomplished merit by casting and writing the true appearance?
Moreover, burning incense
is also not the fragrant incense with characteristics in the world.
It is the incense of the unconditioned true Dharma.
It perfumes all defiled evil karmas, causing them to be completely extinguished.
The incense of the true Dharma has five kinds of essence.
First, the incense of precepts.
It is said that one can cut off all evils and cultivate all good.
Second, the incense of concentration.
It is said that one's faith in the Mahayana is firm and unwavering.
Third, the fragrance of wisdom.
This refers to always observing internally and externally within the body and mind.
Fourth, the fragrance of liberation.
This refers to being able to sever all bonds of ignorance.
Fifth, the fragrance of the knowledge and vision of liberation.
This refers to the unobstructed illumination of ignorance through constant realization and penetration.
These five fragrances are incomparable in the world.
When the Buddha was in the world, he had his disciples burn these priceless fragrances with the fire of wisdom to make offerings to all Buddhas in the ten directions.
Now, sentient beings are foolish and dull-witted.
They do not understand the true meaning of the TathÄgata.
They only burn worldly fragrances such as agarwood and frankincense with external fire.
How can they hope to obtain the rewards of blessings?
The meaning of scattering flowers is also like this.
This refers to expounding the correct Dharma, which is the flower of merit and virtue.
It benefits sentient beings and spreads to all.
It universally adorns the nature of suchness.
This flower of merit and virtue is praised by the Buddha.
Ultimately abiding, without any period of decay.
If there are people who scatter such flowers, they will obtain immeasurable blessings.
If the Tathagata were to have sentient beings cut up silk and brocade,
And further damage grass and trees to make scattered flowers,
This would not be the case.
Why is it so?
Those who uphold pure precepts should not allow the myriad phenomena on the vast earth to be violated.
Those who mistakenly violate it will incur great offenses.
How much more so for now intentionally violating precepts and harming myriad things in pursuit of blessings and rewards?
Desiring to benefit but instead causing harm,ğŸ”½How could this be so?

the mind as the lamp bowl,

and increasing various precepts as adding oil.
The illumination of wisdom is likened to the constant burning of the lamp.
Thus, the lamp of true suchness and right enlightenment illuminates and destroys all the darkness of ignorance and delusion.
One is able to use this Dharma to enlighten others in turn.

To uphold means to protect.
It means that one must restrain the six senses, control the three poisons, diligently observe and purify body and mind in accordance with the Dharma.

It means always seeking good vows whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down.
